awd_titl_txt: Polymer-Based Capsules of Active Liquids Templated by Non-Aqueous Emulsions
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Scientists and engineers continue to develop new materials with improved performance in applications such as batteries, water purification, gas uptake, and so on. These novel materials provide the foundation used to create new technologies that impact and improve nearly every facet of modern life. Unfortunately, some of the new materials, such as ionic liquids and eutectic solvents, are difficult to handle by themselves, and they require containment of some kind, limiting their use in practical systems. This research work addresses these current limitations by developing methods to prepare capsules with cores of the specialized liquid wrapped in polymer shells. This approach is made possible by the use of a water-free emulsion that is composed of droplets of the active liquid dispersed in an oil, coupled with polymerization techniques. The water-free emulsions are critical to the development of this encapsulation system, as they allow the specialized liquid to remain pure and unadulterated. The work addresses how the composition of the polymer shell impacts performance properties of the capsules, namely mechanical properties and the uptake of gaseous carbon dioxide. This research promotes progress in the areas of composite materials with applications in critical areas such as energy storage and gas separations. In addition to the research, this project will support the training of undergraduate and graduate students and development of How-To Videos. These videos are planned to be publicly available and to show new researchers how to use scientific instruments to characterize polymer-based materials, thereby supporting the development and training of scientists and engineers more broadly. 


TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The goal of the planned research is to develop methods to prepare capsules with cores of active liquids (e.g., ionic liquids and deep eutectic solvents) and polymer composite shells of varied permeability, stability, and mechanical properties. This will be accomplished by leveraging interfacial polymerizations in non-aqueous emulsions. Alkylated graphene oxide (GO) nanosheets will be used as particle surfactant to stabilizing Pickering emulsions, toluene or octane will be used as the continuous phase, and ionic liquid or deep eutectic solvent as the discontinuous phase. Aim 1 focuses on preparing capsule shells of varied permeability and mechanical properties using telechelic oligomers as monomers, as prepared by ring opening metathesis polymerization (ROMP), reversible-addition fragmentation-chain transfer (RAFT) polymerization, and radical dead-end polymerization (DEP). In Aim 2, the stability of the capsule shell will be tuned by incorporation of dynamic covalent bonds; this will enable destruction or fusion of the capsule shells. In Aim 3, the capsule shell thickness will be minimized and the core fluid purity maximized by using reactive particle surfactants and thiol-ene chemistry. The capsule composition, morphology, thermal properties, permeability, and mechanical properties will be established. An unfunded collaboration with Prof. Burcu Gurkan will reveal the relationship between shell composition and permeability to gaseous CO2.  An unfunded collaboration with Prof. George Pharr will support evaluation of individual capsules using micromanipulation techniques, producing force-displacement profiles. The scientific research is complemented by support of undergraduate and graduate researchers, as well as How-To Videos (HTVs) which demonstrate working principles and practical considerations for techniques used to characterize soft matter.
.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. This three-year grant advanced knowledge on how to perform polymerizations in emulsions to produce composite structures, enabling the analysis of structure-property relationships for different applications, including thermal energy management and carbon capture. Emulsions have droplets of one liquid dispersed in another such that formation of a polymer shells at the interface of the droplet produces a liquid core with polymer shell. The use of solid particles as surfactant produces particle-polymer-liquid composites that could not be produced in any other way. This work advanced the understanding of how to control the composition and structure of polymer-based composites to: i) enable shell fusion or destruction by tailoring the chemistry of the shell; ii) integrate multifunctional properties or produce pristine core liquids by controlling particle surfactants; and iii) produce bicontinuous emulsions and double emulsions, beyond traditional emulsions. In addition to these major areas, this work also supported the development of inks for additive manufacturing by controlling the polymer chemistry of the ink and capsule additives.

We developed methods to produce liquid-filled capsules with polymer shells containing dynamic covalent bonds which are stable at room temperature but activated when heated. Isolated capsules could be put into a mold and heated such that bond exchange between capsule shells converted the powder to a single structure. We demonstrated that two different dynamic covalent bonds could be used: hindered urea bonds and disulfide bonds. Only capsules with a non-polar oil could be isolated with hindered urea bonds, whereas disulfide bonds in the polymer shells allowed isolation of capsules with a polar liquid, such as an ionic liquid. Thus, the identity of the liquid core impacts the stability of the capsule shell. Notably, the fused capsules containing ionic liquid could be used to capture gaseous CO2.

We established that silica particles could be modified to contain functional groups that both enable them to serve as surfactants and as initiators polymerization. The common technique to make capsules uses one monomer in the droplet and another in the continuous phase, but these new surfactant particles enabled a pristine liquid droplet to be used and significantly expands the composite systems that could be produced. We demonstrated the importance of this new approach by growing a polymer shell around a salt hydrate phase change material core, demonstrating use in thermal energy management. We also demonstrated that transition metal carbide nanosheets (MXenes) could be used to stabilize emulsions, and that MXene nanosheets modified with hydrophobic alkyl groups stabilize water-free emulsions, significantly expanding the types of monomer that could be used to produce MXene-containing capsules, foams, and polymer particles.

The ability to control emulsion structure, beyond simple droplets in a liquid, gives access to different polymer composite morphologies. We demonstrated the production of bicontinuous emulsions by developing a pseudo-ternary morphology map of monomer, water, and graphene oxide nanosheets and demonstrated the production of a solid structure with continuous void throughout; such high surface area structures had unprecedented heating response upon application of radiofrequency and can find use in separations and remediation. We further developed a method to produce double emulsions in which one type of droplet is in another which is in a continuous phase. By incorporating monomers in the outer droplet, we demonstrated the production of capsules with a pristine liquid core, effectively “shrink wrapping” a polymer shell around the droplet. When ionic liquid was encapsulated using this new double emulsion technique, the capsules could be used for carbon capture.  

Broader Impacts. This cross-disciplinary work supported the scientific training of undergraduate and graduate students in developing research plans, carrying out experiments, collecting and analyzing data, and disseminating research outcomes. Twenty-two peer reviewed publications at leading journals were reported, and the PI and graduate students working on this project shared the scientific outcomes through numerous presentations at national and international conferences. This work partially supported five PhD students (including three dissertations completed and two in progress), one MS thesis, and four undergraduate students. Further, multiple How To Videos were recorded and shared with the public through YouTube; graduate and undergraduate students developed scripts and recorded short videos on how to use shared equipment at the Soft Matter Facility at Texas A&M University, and these videos are used to train (and refresh) users.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/02/2024
Modified by: Emily B Pentzer
